summary: Foreshadowing of Jon and Sansa Marriage? - Dornishman’s Wife Song
title: Foreshadowing of Jon and Sansa Marriage? - Dornishman’s Wife Song
body:
While researching some information for a post, I came across an interesting article in a Game of Thrones Wiki page.  In season five, episode 6 (Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken),  Bronn sings the song The Dornishman’s Wife while he and Jaimie Lannister are on their way to Dorne.  When Jaime interrupts his song, Bronn retorts, "This song really is all about the ending”.  

The line by Bronn has lead some readers to theorize that the song contains a clue about how Game of Thrones ends up, and a closer look at the episode gives a possible interpretation.

First, here are the actual lyrics to the song (from the books):


The Dornishman’s wife was as fair as the sun,

and her kisses were warmer than spring.

But the Dornishman’s blade was made of black steel,

and its kiss was a terrible thing.

The Dornishman’s wife would sing as she bathed,

in a voice that was sweet as a peach,

But the Dornishman’s blade had a song of its own,

and a bite sharp and cold as a leech.

As he lay on the ground with the darkness around,

and the taste of his blood on his tongue,

His brothers knelt by him and prayed him a prayer

and he smiled and he laughed and he sung,

“Brothers, oh brothers, my days here are done,

the Dornishman’s taken my life,

But what does it matter, for all men must die,

and I’ve tasted the Dornishman’s wife!”


The lyrics are quite obtuse in that they don’t exactly match what I think the clue is, but here it goes: 

The “Dornishman” is Jon Snow and he has Valyrian Steel

This is pretty obvious if you think about it.  Jon Snow was born in Dorne, and he possesses a black steel blade, i.e., Valyrian Steel.

Who is the Dornishman’s Wife?

If this episode, Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken is truly meant to contain a clue related to the song, there is one to be found right in the episode.  This is the episode in which Sansa  marries Ramsay Bolton, but first she is shown taking a bath, which is mentioned in the above lyric.  Sansa does not literally “sing” in the bath; however she does tell Myranda “I am Sansa Stark of Winterfell, and this is my home…”.  Sansa washes the darker color out of her hair so that it becomes red again.  In a symbolic sense this declaration is indeed Sansa’s “song”.  Her arc is all about restoring the Stark name, and this also becomes Jon’s song when they reunite in season 6.

The Next Verse is Garbled but it could be about Jon, Ramsay, or even Bronn

The final part the song seems to allude to Jon’s assassination by a mutinous faction of the Night’s Watch, but the singer also states “The Dornishman’s taken my life”  and “I’ve tasted the Dornishman’s wife”.  If the song is really about Sansa, than it could be a prophecy about Ramsay’s death (he “tasted” Sansa, unfortunately). Although Jon didn’t literally kill Ramsay, he almost did.  An alternative explanation may have something to do with Bronn’s actions in season 8, as Jerome Flynn (the actor who plays him) has hinted that Bronn may take a darker turn.  If Bronn allies with Cersei for some reason, maybe he will be implicated in a plot involving Sansa.

It seems clear that if this song does indeed provide a veiled reference to the ending of Game of Thrones, the “Dornishman” would have to be  Jon Snow.  The Dornishman’s “wife” is a more difficult reference; however in the very episode in which the song is featured, Sansa is shown taking a bath and talking about the Starks and Winterfell.  Interestingly, in this same episode (before he makes his remark about the “ending), Bronn sings only the first half of the song.  The end of the song is sung by him in another episode, The Gift.

blog.name: wallofprompts
blog.title: The Wall of Prompts
blog.description: GoT prompts. Grab a prompt for a fic or left one. Main ships Jonerys and Gendrya, but everyone is welcome. Check the tags list for prompts.

title: Jaimsa forced marriage prompt
body:
Jaime arrives at King’s Landing earlier, so instead of marrying Sansa to Tyrion, Lord Tywin expels Jaime from the King’s guard as he wanted and forces Jaime to marry Sansa.

Tywin also forces Cersei to marry Balon Greyjoy, in order to stop the rumours about Cersei and Jaime, secure a future heir to The North and bring the Iron Islands back into the fold.

Being rejected by Cersei and changed after his time with Brienne, Jaime takes advantage when his father sends him and his new wife to Casterly Rock, to scape their retinue with Brienne and Podrick’s help and ride to the Riverlands to deliver Sansa to her family.

summary:
My new take on the Ep 2 (?) Dany-library-smiling-scene:
She and Sansa are talking about Arya and Gendry a lá Dany and Missandei...
body:
My new take on the Ep 2 (?) Dany-library-smiling-scene:

She and Sansa are talking about Arya and Gendry a lá Dany and Missandei talking about Grey Worm.

I thought at first it would be Arya who would warm up to Dany the fastest but once Arya and Gendry start *hem* getting closer and Jon learns his parentage, Sansa will likely be sibling-less for a while. And Jon will probably distance himself from Dany too so with Jon off being broody and Arya with Gendry, I seriously think this will be what binds Sansa and Dany together.

They’ll be isolated and realize, oh, hey, you don’t have a friend right now either. Let’s talk. And then before we know it, they’re giggling about Arya and Gendry spending way too much time alone in the forge late at night, something about them doing “many things” in there, Dany gives Sansa the blue ascot/scarf thing that matches hers, and antis can finally STFU. :D

f: a song of ice and fire
summary:
J/on Snow relinquished his crown and the North’s sovereignty to a 
would-be ruler who up to that point had never even set foot...
body:
J/on Snow relinquished his crown and the North’s sovereignty to a would-be ruler who up to that point had never even set foot in the region and shown zero understanding of either its old or recent history. He did so willingly, after D/aenerys had stopped asking him to bend the knee, and knowing full well that he was going against the wishes of both the Northeners and Sansa who wanted to remain an independent kingdom. All because, as it was implied, he caught feelings for D/aenerys.

Sansa meanwhile literally 1) offered up the lordship to Bran when he came back, 2) refused to overthrow Jon and steal the crown for herself when the Lords suggested it.

Instead she held the North as Lady of Winterfell during Jon’s absence, kept the peace among his subjects and prepared the castle and armies for the battles to come and the influx of refugees to expect.

Yet I still have to see people licking Jon’s ass while calling Sansa the traitor.

And sidenote, because you are so fucking stupid and love blaming her for her father’s death: in the show, Sansa never went to Cersei or anyone else to tell them that her father was planning on leaving and heading back to Winterfell. As for the novel, how the fuck is an 11 year old responsible for the acts committed by the literal adults around her that she fully believed to be trustworthy.

But I guess having braincells would make it difficult for you demons to hate on her.

trail.content:
J/on Snow relinquished his crown and the North’s sovereignty to a would-be ruler who up to that point had never even set foot in the region and shown zero understanding of either its old or recent history. He did so willingly, after D/aenerys had stopped asking him to bend the knee, and knowing full well that he was going against the wishes of both the Northeners and Sansa who wanted to remain an independent kingdom. All because, as it was implied, he caught feelings for D/aenerys.

Sansa meanwhile literally 1) offered up the lordship to Bran when he came back, 2) refused to overthrow Jon and steal the crown for herself when the Lords suggested it.

Instead she held the North as Lady of Winterfell during Jon’s absence, kept the peace among his subjects and prepared the castle and armies for the battles to come and the influx of refugees to expect.

Yet I still have to see people licking Jon’s ass while calling Sansa the traitor.

And sidenote, because you are so fucking stupid and love blaming her for her father’s death: in the show, Sansa never went to Cersei or anyone else to tell them that her father was planning on leaving and heading back to Winterfell. As for the novel, how the fuck is an 11 year old responsible for the acts committed by the literal adults around her that she fully believed to be trustworthy.

But I guess having braincells would make it difficult for you demons to hate on her.

blog.name: ai-megurine
blog.title: Ai Megurine
blog.description: I'm a bisexual happy-go-lucky Hufflepuff girl who enjoys unicorns, nu goth and pastel goth, mangas, SANSA STARK, runes, Luka Megurine Hinata Hyūga, Gaara and Gaahina.

title: Sansa Stark the Hufflepuff
body:
I have always seen people discuss whether Sansa is a Ravenclaw or a Slytherin, but I see her as a Hufflepuff, to be honest. Before murdering me, let me defend my idea ^^ According to Wikia, here are the Hufflepuff attributes: dedication, hardworking, fairness, patience, kindness, tolerance, modesty and loyalty. Let us proceed attribute by attribute.

1.      Dedication.

           Sansa embodies dedication. She worked hard to become a perfect lady (see 2.), she wants to be the perfect wife for Joffrey and a good queen, she looks after Sweet Robin even though he needs a lot of attention (due to his seizures and many problems, poor kid) and acts like the Lady of the Erye even though it demands a lot of work, etc.

2.      Hardworking

           According to her own mother, “Sansa was a lady at three”. Even though Sansa was obviously a natural when it came to be a lady, she had to work to be as good as she is. She can play several instruments, write poetry, sew her own clothes (and lady clothes are harder to do than low-born clothes because embroidery is hard), but she also is a walking encyclopaedia when she is 11, which shows that she worked hard to remember Houses, knights, etc. You have to work hard to know how to do these things as well as Sansa does, which means than she is a hard worker.

3.      Fairness

           I do not think that this attribute has much development. I do not remember her being unfair, to be honest, but I can be wrong. And no, her treatment of Jon is not unfair simply because they did not interact. Jon and Sansa have no common interest, and her ignoring him is not “unfair”. Sansa obeys the rules of society, but still remains kind. It would have been so easy for her to be unfair! She could accuse him of any wrongdoings she wanted, and people would have believed her. And, by the way, every single Stark kid calls Jon “my bastard half-brother” or “my half-brother”. Her treatment of Jon is the only moment when we could see Sansa being unfair, but she was not.

           When you look at Westerosi culture, she was not being unfair to him. Even when you read Jon’s chapters, he does not remember Sansa as someone horrible, who treated badly. He does note that she referred to him as his half-brother since she was old enough to understand what a bastard was, but he remembers her singing while brushing Lady’s fur (ergo a recent memory) and telling him he must always compliment a girl’s name, meaning they had some kind of interactions.

4.      Patience

           Even though we see Sansa being impatient once or twice (when she snaps at Ser Dontos because she is desperate for example, and as I just said, she was desperate and had been suffering from physical and psychological abuses for months), she is incredibly patient, and this is what saves her: if she had been more impulsive, she would have been killed on spot by Joffrey. But she was patient: she waited for Robb to come and save her, for Dontos’ plan, etc. In comparison, Arya is quite impatient (this is not an attack, simply a comparison to show Sansa’s patience!), as seen when she tries to escape the men of the Brotherhood Without Banner when they capture her, for example.

5.      Kindness

           I am not sure that I have to prove Sansa’s kindness: she saves Dontos, covers Arya, cares for Sweet Robin, she would have given bread to the angry mob if she had any, etc. Sansa is kind, there is nothing you can say which will make me think otherwise.

6.      Tolerance

           Sansa is someone I see as quite tolerant through her religious background: even though she prefers the Faith of the Seven, she also believes in the Old Gods, and goes to the weird wood. It demonstrates that she is open-minded, even though we do not have much info on this subject and thus I cannot really say anything. We can also note that she does not think ill of Ellaria Sand, who is a bastard and, even though we see the scene through Tyrion’s eyes, it would have been easy to write as being uneasy when talking to Ellaria (for example, Ollena called Ellaria a “whore”). Thus, I think Sansa is pretty tolerant considering Westerosi standards.

7.      Modesty

           Correct me if I am wrong, but I do not remember Sansa bragging. She says that she is stupid and silly (“I’m just being silly”) and never seems arrogant. Even Arya, who used to have a very biased description of her sister due to her self-confidence issues, does not see her as arrogant.

8.      Loyalty

           No matter what, Sansa remained loyal to her House. Each time Robb won a battle, Sansa bled for the North. She was beaten and humiliated for Joffrey’s pleasure, but she remained loyal to her house. She wanted to raise her sons to hate the Lannisters because she is loyal to the Starks and wants nothing but going home. It is literally the first thing she asked to Cersei when she was freed from her betrothal to Joffrey. Sansa wants to go home.

           In conclusion, I think Sansa is someone who would perfectly fit in Hufflepuff. Is she brave, cunning, etc? Of course; everyone fits in several Hogwart House. However, you are sorted in a House whose attributes corresponds to those you value the most! And Sansa does not value her Slytherin (resourcefulness, self-preservation, cleverness, etc) or Ravenclaw (Intelligence, wit, wisdom) abilities above what comes naturally to her: dedication, hardworking, fairness, patience, kindness, tolerance, modesty and loyalty.

(And yes, I wanted to sort my favourite in my House but I think I have some pretty valid arguments, don’t I?)

She was beaten and humiliated for Joffrey’s pleasure, but she remained loyal to her house. She wanted to raise her sons to hate the Lannisters because she is loyal to the Starks and wants nothing but going home. It is literally the first thing she asked to Cersei when she was freed from her betrothal to Joffrey. Sansa wants to go home.

           In conclusion, I think Sansa is someone who would perfectly fit in Hufflepuff. Is she brave, cunning, etc? Of course; everyone fits in several Hogwart House. However, you are sorted in a House whose attributes corresponds to those you value the most! And Sansa does not value her Slytherin (resourcefulness, self-preservation, cleverness, etc) or Ravenclaw (Intelligence, wit, wisdom) abilities above what comes naturally to her: dedication, hardworking, fairness, patience, kindness, tolerance, modesty and loyalty.

(And yes, I wanted to sort my favourite in my House but I think I have some pretty valid arguments, don’t I?)

summary: I love how you like to claim that femininity is some kind of western invention. Also got is one show among the myriad of show...
question: I love how you like to claim that femininity is some kind of western invention. Also got is one show among the myriad of show were traditional feminine women are held up as the ideal. Maybe read stuff by women from non-western countries(SK, Nigeria, Brazil, Japan) and how they talk about the detriments of femininity and girls/women being forced to conform to it. I was raised in Nigeria and I've been living in the US for over 10 yrs seeing idiots like you deny it disgusts me.
answer:
The only person I see with a shallow understanding of sexism is your dumbass. In fact it’s clear you actually don’t understand sexism at all or why we women experience what we do at the hands of men. To explain it to idiots like you femininity is not innate. No girl or woman has ever been born feminine. However, feminine women are not worthless or useless b/c they conform to the desire of their society. This is basic stuff for anyone who actually gives a fuck about women.

Also did white people force Chinese men to get a fetish for small feet forcing Chinese girls to have their feet bound, broken, and deformed to make themselves feminine and attractive to these men? Are you so stupid that you don’t know that that is femininity? Being able to knit or sew is not inherently feminine but has been deemed so by men to devalue women’s skills b/c men know that by calling things feminine aka relating it w/women it is akin to putting it down.

And as someone who only cares about Sansa from got and has liked multiple feminine female characters and will continue to do so w/o any problems seeing you spreading lies and bullshit about traditional femininity in our society and in the media is repulsive. You also have the audacity to shit on and put down women who are actually telling the truth about the reality for women around the world in regards to femininity while deluding yourself into thinking you’re in the right is embarrassing.

Can you read? Do you need classes because I’m struggling to see where I said femininity is a western invention? I feel like talking about how western centric this website and its discourses are gives you physical pain to make you this mad. Nice to see you skipped over the point about colonialism and really everything else. Anon, you simpleton, my point was that maybe be more intersectional with your feminism which is apparently far beyond your capabilities. Yes, anon, feminine behaviour is taught just like masculine behaviour is taught because we live in a society and that involves socialisation. You can take a break after every sentence because I can tell it’s really difficult for you to follow along. Yes, anon, women are oppressed everywhere including Nigeria which you have definitely been to. Yes, the patriarchy has destroyed the bodies and lives of women. I have not disputed any of this, you just came here to be angry. The way you, a Nigerian/America or wherever you’re actually from, react to characters on TV isn’t the same as me. I’m not worried about lipstick on Carol Danvers so much as colorism because lipstick isn’t as prevalent in my society. So characters you think are over-represented or whatever aren’t imo. Saying that all feminine characters aren’t groundbreaking is untrue for female characters belonging to marginalised groups.

My issue is that you are all focusing your anger on feminine women instead of the patriarchy to the point of lying about them being held up as ideals in Game of Thrones and other shows (my favourite part of your ask is your claim that Sansa is held up as ideal in GOT lmao). Which is it anon, are feminine women devalued or are they idealised? It can’t be both because femininity is tied to womanhood (which yes isn’t a single thing, is fluid, a spectrum etc etc) and women are looked down on everywhere. You can take another break, I know your brain is hurting from having to read so much. The problem with posts like that is it wasn’t telling the reality of women the world over which was my point, the sexism I live through is affected by colonialism, islamophobia, ethnophobia etc. Also the usual arguments of destructive beauty standards like fighting in heels or inappropriate clothing aren’t present in Sansa which was @cmollyo and @cleverjonquil‘s point. That’s why they said ‘Sansa begs to defer.’ Whatever OP and others were complaining about can’t be applied to every female character.

My favourite thing about this anon is them getting mad because I don’t think feminine women should get attacked, that femininity isn’t celebrated and I think Sansa is a groundbreaking character on TV. How many Sansas in fantasy series do you know anon who supposedly likes many feminine characters on TV?

blog.name: moonlitgleek
blog.title: Welcome to the dark side
blog.description: Sam. Late twenties. Rant-aholic. Multinfandom blog. Glee, Game of Thrones\ASOIAF. Other shows include The Flash, Sense8, Grey's Anatomy, Criminal Minds, HTGAWM, Supergirl, Quantico, AHS.

summary: Hallo.  I've read ASOIAF and a lot of metas concerning the books and it seems that in TWOW Dany and Tyrion are two heroes who...
question: Hallo.  I've read ASOIAF and a lot of metas concerning the books and it seems that in TWOW Dany and Tyrion are two heroes who are going to take darker paths.  Dany giving in to her dragon side and Tyrion becoming even more nihilistic than he was in ADWD.  I also think that the Starks (including Jon Snow) will take darker paths in TWOW.  I believe the danger they face is that they will let the cold in and all the horrors that they have suffered will cause them to become more callous 1/2
answer:
I love Dany, Tyrion and all the Starks and it will be interesting to see them grapple with and defeat their own inner monsters and I have every confidence that they will.  Jon has become Lord Snow, where he forced Gilly to swap her baby and Sansa, Arya and Bran are being mentored by people who don’t seem the sort to encourage things like compassion and empathy in their protogees.  Can you say what the dark paths might be for Sansa, Arya and Bran? 2/2

I would not put it as them grappling with their inner monster because monster is a loaded term that’s been used particularly with Tyrion to denote an inherent moral rot which largely feeds into Tyrion’s breakdown and spiral in ADWD because “you make me sorry that I am not the monster you would have me be”. An expectation of monstrosity as an unchangeable trait of Tyrion’s broke him down to a point that set him on the dark path he is currently on. But people don’t innately have an inner monster that they need to defeat to be good or compassionate.

That said, I do agree that we’re going to see the Big Six taking darker paths in TWoW. They are all already on their way there to varying extents but the slide is perhaps clearer in some stories than others. Bran is one of the characters who is reasonably into that part of his arc with his repeated skinchanging into Hodor. Skinchanging a human has been established as an abomination and a pretty terrible thing to do that it’s been described as akin to rape. Thistle brutalizes herself in her resistance to Varamyr’s violation of her mind, and Hodor is always quietly terrified of Bran’s intrusion that he retreats into his own mind. Yet Bran keeps skinchanging Hodor and using his body to do what he wants disregarding Hodor’s agency, consent, bodily autonomy and abject fear and hatred of what Bran is forcing on him, which will come to head with the incident of “hold the door” when Bran forces Hodor to sacrifice himself for Bran’s and Meera’s survival. That repeated violation of Hodor’s personhood and autonomy is informed by a great deal of ableism on Bran’s part since he stops treating Hodor as a person and instead turns him into a means to an end, a meat suit to ride and give back when he is done. But Hodor’s body isn’t Bran’s to use and ultimately Bran has to recognize that he has monumentally violated a person, a loyal friend who has been instrumental in Bran’s journey no less, to his grave largely because he dismissed Hodor’s personhood due to his disability.

Arya’s darker path will probably have to do with the possibility of her giving into vengeance. Her story has had motifs of vengeance and justice for the longest time, and the principles of the House of Black and White are one more stressor she has to contend with. While most of Arya’s kills have fallen on the justice side, she has killed on the kindly man’s orders, and she is set for a confrontation with the Faceless Men over her unlicensed kill of Raff the Sweetling that might push her to focus on her list as she fully reclaims the identity of Arya Stark. I think Arya returns to Westeros with the express goal of finishing off those on her list as the fine line between vengeance and justice gets really blurred. Meeting Lady Stoneheart and BwB will be the culmination of that arc in that it demonstrates the possible perils of having vengeance as a goal, how easy it is for justice and vengeance to get conflated, and how killing the people on her list won’t make her feel better. It is a return to “Joffrey was dead, but if Robb was dead too, what did it matter?” that will shift Arya’s path back to seeking out her siblings rather than trying to cross names off her list.

Sansa’s arc will probably revolve around a question of complicity. Littlefinger has put a lot of effort into making Sansa his accomplice. He made her a part of Joffrey’s murder without her knowledge but then shifted to making her a conscious accomplice in his schemes by involving her in the coverup of Lysa’s murder and framing Marillion. And despite the fact that Sansa hasn’t put it together yet, Littlefinger is fairly open about a few of his more nefarious plans with her. But she does have the necessary information to eventually deduce that he is the one behind Jon Arryn’s murder and that he is currently slowly poisoning Robert Arryn. I think Sansa reaches a point where she realizes the more egregious of Petyr’s crimes and faces the choice of keeping her silence or exposing him. I suspect that learning about Petyr’s betrayal of Ned and/or what he did to Jeyne Poole might be the tipping point in her arc.

I would not put it as them grappling with their inner monster because monster is a loaded term that’s been used particularly with Tyrion to denote an inherent moral rot which largely feeds into Tyrion’s breakdown and spiral in ADWD because “you make me sorry that I am not the monster you would have me be”. An expectation of monstrosity as an unchangeable trait of Tyrion’s broke him down to a point that set him on the dark path he is currently on. But people don’t innately have an inner monster that they need to defeat to be good or compassionate.

That said, I do agree that we’re going to see the Big Six taking darker paths in TWoW. They are all already on their way there to varying extents but the slide is perhaps clearer in some stories than others. Bran is one of the characters who is reasonably into that part of his arc with his repeated skinchanging into Hodor. Skinchanging a human has been established as an abomination and a pretty terrible thing to do that it’s been described as akin to rape. Thistle brutalizes herself in her resistance to Varamyr’s violation of her mind, and Hodor is always quietly terrified of Bran’s intrusion that he retreats into his own mind. Yet Bran keeps skinchanging Hodor and using his body to do what he wants disregarding Hodor’s agency, consent, bodily autonomy and abject fear and hatred of what Bran is forcing on him, which will come to head with the incident of “hold the door” when Bran forces Hodor to sacrifice himself for Bran’s and Meera’s survival. That repeated violation of Hodor’s personhood and autonomy is informed by a great deal of ableism on Bran’s part since he stops treating Hodor as a person and instead turns him into a means to an end, a meat suit to ride and give back when he is done. But Hodor’s body isn’t Bran’s to use and ultimately Bran has to recognize that he has monumentally violated a person, a loyal friend who has been instrumental in Bran’s journey no less, to his grave largely because he dismissed Hodor’s personhood due to his disability.

Arya’s darker path will probably have to do with the possibility of her giving into vengeance. Her story has had motifs of vengeance and justice for the longest time, and the principles of the House of Black and White are one more stressor she has to contend with. While most of Arya’s kills have fallen on the justice side, she has killed on the kindly man’s orders, and she is set for a confrontation with the Faceless Men over her unlicensed kill of Raff the Sweetling that might push her to focus on her list as she fully reclaims the identity of Arya Stark. I think Arya returns to Westeros with the express goal of finishing off those on her list as the fine line between vengeance and justice gets really blurred. Meeting Lady Stoneheart and BwB will be the culmination of that arc in that it demonstrates the possible perils of having vengeance as a goal, how easy it is for justice and vengeance to get conflated, and how killing the people on her list won’t make her feel better. It is a return to “Joffrey was dead, but if Robb was dead too, what did it matter?” that will shift Arya’s path back to seeking out her siblings rather than trying to cross names off her list.

Sansa’s arc will probably revolve around a question of complicity. Littlefinger has put a lot of effort into making Sansa his accomplice. He made her a part of Joffrey’s murder without her knowledge but then shifted to making her a conscious accomplice in his schemes by involving her in the coverup of Lysa’s murder and framing Marillion. And despite the fact that Sansa hasn’t put it together yet, Littlefinger is fairly open about a few of his more nefarious plans with her. But she does have the necessary information to eventually deduce that he is the one behind Jon Arryn’s murder and that he is currently slowly poisoning Robert Arryn. I think Sansa reaches a point where she realizes the more egregious of Petyr’s crimes and faces the choice of keeping her silence or exposing him. I suspect that learning about Petyr’s betrayal of Ned and/or what he did to Jeyne Poole might be the tipping point in her arc.

body: I love how Jonsa/Sansa stans constantly get accused of not understanding the characters yet with the leaks and interviews lately we’ve been consistently proven right about not only Sansa but Arya, Sam, Lyanna Mormont, the North as a whole, etc…
